Message.Title: Apple: "Android is a stolen product."
Message.Msg: . . Apple: "Android is a stolen product." . . Apple, Google CEOs Said to Discuss Patent Disputes By Brian Womack and Adam Satariano - Aug 30, 2012 3:34 PM CT In excerpts. Apple Inc. (AAPL) Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook and Google Inc. (GOOG) CEO Larry Page are holding discussions regarding patent disputes involving the two leading technology companies, said a person with knowledge of the talks. Cook and Page spoke by phone last week and are expected to talk more soon, said the person, who asked not to be named because the conversations aren’t public. The person didn’t elaborate on the details of the discussions. Apple is embroiled in lawsuits with several makers of smartphones that use Google’s Android operating system. Apple last week won a $1.05 billion verdict from a California jury, which found that features of some of Samsung Electronics Co.’s Android-based phones infringed patents for the iPhone. Samsung’s stock tumbled the most in almost four years after the verdict. Even though Apple hasn’t sued Google directly, the iPhone maker’s patent lawsuits against Samsung and HTC Corp. (2498) have targeted features from Android. Apple co-founder Steve Jobs told biographer Walter Isaacson that Android was a “stolen product.” Apple considered suing Google directly before filing its first smartphone patent-infringement suit against HTC in 2010, according to a person close to Apple’s legal team. Apple decided against it after determining that going after the manufacturers of rival smartphones would be a better strategy than building a case against Google, this person said. The Android developer, also owner of the most popular Internet- search engine, gives the mobile operating system away for free to handset makers in exchange for advertising revenue. . . . "Oh, chit! -- Cook's got a radar lock on us. Get out of there, man! I'm hit. I'm hit, We're coming apart. I can't control it! We're going down....." . . .

Topic.Title: Apple Seeks Ban on Eight Samsung Phones in U.S.

Message.Msg: Come on. The patents violated are hardly earth-shatering. With nearly all of them being in the software implementation they could develop workarounds by the end of the year. How long do you think it takes for a designer and developer to come up with something other than square buttons or the end-of-list bounce-back. Other patents, like multi-touch, will be more difficult to work around. Whole bloody thing is a bit ridiculous if you ask me though... putting a patent on a square, a rectangle or on touching a touchable screen more than once at a time. It is what it is though and we'll be paying for it. Most patents will be worked around in future models though... multi-touch, if it sticks, will win Apple some royalties.
Yeah, seems to have slowed board activity way down. I don't like this new format at all !!!!!!!!!!!!! Whomever thought of this new format obviously doesn't use these boards !!!!!

Topic.Title: Apple Seeks Ban on Eight Samsung Phones in U.S.

Message.Msg: Actually that multi-touch patent only covers the ability to interact with a frame or part of a web page without affecting the rest of the page using multiple touches. This is a very narrow definition and very little functionality is lost by simply using multiple touches to interact with the whole page rather than only a part. I don't think phone manufactures will have much trouble designing phones which do not violate these patents (like they should have done in the first place).

Message.Title: Samsung slips into AMD's HSA party, may seek parallel processing boost for Exynos
Message.Msg: Trust us, this should ultimately make a lot of sense. As we already know, AMD recently set up the HSA Foundation1 to promote its vision for better parallel processing -- and especially GPU compute2 -- in mobiles and PCs. Its semi-rival ARM was one of the first big players to join up, and now Samsung has decided to hop onboard too. Why would it do that? For the simple reason that the Korean company still makes its own chips, based on ARM designs, and we've seen that GPU compute is going to be a big feature in its coming Exynos 5 processor3 with Mali T604 graphics. Now, anything else at this point is pure speculation, since we only know about Samsung's HSA membership from the appearance of its logo on a relevant slide at AMD's keynote speech at IFA4, and there's no official word on Samsung's intentions. At a bare minimum, the company could simply be firming up friendships5 and hedging its bets on the future of computing. We wouldn't be surprised, however, if Sammy is looking to work with ARM and AMD to implement further aspects of the HSA philosophy into even more advanced Exynos chips down the line -- chips that are able to use both GPU compute and smaller transistors6 to achieve leaps in performance while also gobbling fewer volts.

Topic.Title: Let's see how many "best" derived Yahoo IDs the new board would allow....

Message.Msg: . . Fiscally GRIM. That's what Our nvidia Message Board is. In fiscally grim shape, boys. Best just read the entire Yahoo! 10-K looking for a glimse into the relative significance of these Message Boards to Yahoo!. You know, the "unique" number of readers, revenues, margins etc. Conclusion: It's grim, grim, grim, boys. There is Not One Mention in the entire Yahoo! 10-K of our precious Yahoo Finance Message Board. None. Nada. Goose egg. Yahoo Finance gets a passing half-paragraph mention -- about how Yahoo sunk "between $10 million and $100 million into Yahoo Finance" like a decade ago -- and have 200 data providers -- but Nothing about revenues -- let alone those elusive profits. Looks a lot like that failed Tegra experiment. . . It appears boys, that the only way Our message board ever turns a nickel is from the "click-on" ad boxes -- for like E*TRADE or Scottrade. Maybe they get $10 bucks a click from the advertiser, right? Hardly enough to employee a fine Yahoo! Monitor. Part time. Which, by the way, might explain the long lag time between reporting a perpetrator, and their actual disappearance from Our fine board. . . So here's the Plan, boys. If the only visible sign of revenue to our poor impoverished board is the "click-on" ad boxes, we all need to click regularly and frequently on those. Click -- $10 bucks to the nvda MB cigar box. Click -- Another $10 bucks for a good Cause. Heck, the Bestville denizens could generate three grand for the Cause in an evening. Kind of like a "fund raising night", right boys? And then maybe open, say, 50 to 60 E*TRADE accounts each. Trade free for 60 days, right boys? Try a couple dozen Scottrade accounts too -- heck why not. If we ALL work together here, we might save our impoverished message board from the chopping block of Yahoo's new Interim CEO lady. . . .
